<doc> Timeout on client side

== Description ==
The functions described in this page implement client //timeouts//.

== Synopsis ==

=== Client ===

   (timeout-start arg ...)
   (timeout-clear! arg ...)
   (timeout-reset! arg ...)

== Server Definitions ==
<client>

=== ++(timeout-start name int proc eager)++ ===
<procedure> timeout-start
<arguments>
^  arguments  ^   type      ^   description                                   ^
| name        |  string     | The identifier of the timeout.                  |
| int         |  integer    | A interval in milli-seconds.                    |
| proc        |  procedure  | The function to executed when interval expires.  |
| eager       |  boolean    | Eager execution if true.                        |
</arguments>

This procedure starts a timeout. Timeouts are identified by their name.
In addition to executing it when //int// expires, //eager// timeouts 
also execute their procedure at creation time.
</procedure>

=== ++(timeout-reset! name int proc)++ ===
<procedure> timeout-reset!
<arguments>
^  arguments  ^   type      ^   description                                   ^
| name        |  string     | The identifier of the timeout.                  |
| int         |  integer    | A interval in milli-seconds.                    |
| proc        |  procedure  | The function to executed when interval expires.  |
</arguments>

Changes the interval and the procedure of the timeout //name//.
</procedure>

=== ++(timeout-clear! name)++ ===
<procedure> timeout-clear!
<arguments>
^  arguments  ^   type      ^   description                                   ^
| name        |  string     | The identifier of the timeout.                  |
</arguments>

Clears (stops and destroys) the timeout //name//.
</procedure>

== See also ==
<see-also>timeout<see-also>
</client>
</doc>
